title: Recognition-Primed Decisions
content: Experienced operators often make rapid, effective decisions by recognizing situations as similar to ones they've encountered before. This recognition-primed decision making works by pattern matchingâ€”the brain identifies the situation type and retrieves proven responses. It's fast and often accurate, but can fail when situations look familiar but are actually different.

mcq.question: A senior operator quickly diagnoses a problem and implements a solution that has worked many times before. This time, the solution doesn't work and the situation worsens. What most likely happened?

options.B: The situation appeared similar but had critical differences
options.C: Pattern recognition doesn't work in operational settings

mcq.explanation: Recognition-primed decisions fail when situations look similar to past experiences but have important differences. The experienced operator correctly recognized a pattern, but the pattern didn't actually apply because of hidden differences in the current situation.

openQuestions: How do you verify that a situation truly matches the pattern you've recognized, rather than just appearing similar?
When has your experience-based intuition been wrong? What made that situation different from what you expected?
